definition:
Let $(X,+,\cdot)$ be a ring. Since $(X,+)$ is required to be an abelian
group, the operation “$+$” necessarily is commutative.

This needs not to happen for “$\cdot$”. Rings $R$ where “$\cdot$” is
commutative, that is, $x\!\cdot\!y = y\!\cdot\!x$ for all $x,y\in R$,
are called commutative rings.

The commutative rings are rings which are more like the fields than
other rings are, but there are certain dissimilarities. A field has
always a multiplicative inverse for each of its nonzero elements, but
the same needs not to be true for a commutative ring. Further, in a
commutative ring there may exist zero divisors, i.e. nonzero elements
having product zero. Since the ideals of a commutative ring are , the
these rings are more comfortable to handle than other rings.

The study of commutative rings is called [*commutative algebra*]{}.
